chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:1
verses.text: A Commentary on the Apostles' Creed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:2
verses.text: This exposition of the Creed was made at the request of Laurentius, a Bishop whose see is unknown, but is conjectured by Fontanini, in his life of Rufinus, to have been Concordia, Rufinus' birthplace.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:3
verses.text: Its exact date cannot be fixed; but from the fact that he says nothing of his difficulty in writing Latin after being so long in the East, as he does in several of his books, and from the comparative ease of the style, it is most probable that it was written in the later years of his sojourn at Aquileia, that is, about 307–309.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:4
verses.text: Its value is considerable (1) as bearing witness to the state of the Creed in local churches at the beginning of the 5th century, especially their variations.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:5
verses.text: (In the church of Aquileia, in Jesu Christo.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:6
verses.text: Patrem invisibilem et impassibilem.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:7
verses.text: Resurrectio hujus carnis); (2) as showing the adaptation of Eastern ideas to the formation of Western theology; (3) as giving the Canon of the books of Scripture, and the Apocrypha of both the Old and New dispensations.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:8
verses.text: The exposition is clear and reasonable; and, with the exception of a very few passages, such as the argument from the Phoenix for the Virgin Birth of our Lord, is still of use to us.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:9
verses.text: We prefix the words of the creed on which Rufinus makes his commentary.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:10
verses.text: It seems desirable to give the original Latin, as well as the English version of the Creed of Aquileia.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:11
verses.text: The words or letters which are peculiar to this creed are put in italics.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:41
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:42
verses.text: My mind has as little inclination for writing as sufficiency, faithful Bishop(Papa) Laurentius, for I well know that it is a matter of no little peril to submit a slender ability to general criticism.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:43
verses.text: But, since in your letter you rashly (forgive my saying so) require me, by Christ's sacraments, which I hold in the greatest reverence, to compose something for you concerning the Faith, in accordance with the traditional and natural meaning of the Creed, although in so doing you impose a burthen upon me beyond my strength to bear (for I do not forget the opinion of the wise, which so justly says, that "to speak of God even what is true is perilous"); still, if you will aid with your prayers the necessity which your requisition has laid upon me, I will try to say something, moved rather by a reverential regard for your injunction than by presumptuous confidence in my ability.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:44
verses.text: What I write, however, will hardly seem worthy of the consideration of persons of mature understanding, but suited rather to the capacity of children and young beginners in Christ.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:45
verses.text: I find, indeed, that some eminent writers have published treatises on these matters piously and briefly written.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:46
verses.text: Moreover, I know that the heretic Photinus has written on the same; but with the object, not of explaining the meaning of the text to his readers, but of wresting things simply and truthfully said in support of his own dogma, while yet the Holy Spirit has taken care that in these words nothing should be set down which is ambiguous or obscure, or inconsistent with other truths: for therein is that prophecy verified, "Finishing and cutting short the word in equity: because a short word will the Lord make upon the earth".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:47
verses.text: It shall be our endeavour, then, first to restore and emphasize the words of the Apostles in their native simplicity; and, secondly, to supply such things as seem to have been omitted by former expositors.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 1:48
verses.text: But that the scope of this "short word," as we have called it, may be made more plain, we will enquire from the beginning how it came to be given to the Churches.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:2
verses.text: Our forefathers have handed down to us the tradition, that, after the Lord's ascension, when, through the coming of the Holy Ghost, tongues of flame had settled upon each of the Apostles, that they might speak diverse languages, so that no race however foreign, no tongue however barbarous, might be inaccessible to them and beyond their reach, they were commanded by the Lord to go severally to the several nations to preach the word of God.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:3
verses.text: Being on the eve therefore of departing from one another, they first mutually agreed upon a standard of their future preaching, lest haply, when separated, they might in any instance vary in the statements which they should make to those whom they should invite to believe in Christ.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:4
verses.text: Being all therefore met together, and being filled with the Holy Ghost, they composed, as we have said, this brief formulary of their future preaching, each contributing his several sentence to one common summary: and they ordained that the rule thus framed should be given to those who believe.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:5
verses.text: To this formulary, for many and most sufficient reasons, they gave the name or Symbol.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:6
verses.text: For Symbol (κύμβολον) in Greek answers to both "Indicium" (a sign or token) and "Collatio" (a joint contribution made by several) in Latin.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:7
verses.text: For this the Apostles did in these words, each contributing his several sentence.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:8
verses.text: It is called "Indicium" or "Signum," a sign or token, because, at that time, as the Apostle Paul says, and as is related in the Acts of the Apostles, many of the vagabond Jews, pretending to be apostles of Christ, went about preaching for gain's sake or their belly's sake, naming the name of Christ indeed, but not delivering their message according to the exact traditional lines.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:9
verses.text: The Apostles therefore prescribed this formulary as a sign or token by which he who preached Christ truly, according to Apostolic rule, might be recognised.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:10
verses.text: Finally, they say that in civil wars, since the armour of both sides is alike, and the language the same, and the custom and mode of warfare the same, each general, to guard against treachery, is wont to deliver to his soldiers a distinct symbol or watchword—in Latin "signum" or "indicium"—so that if one is met with, of whom it is doubtful to which side he belongs, being asked the symbol (watchword), he discloses whether he is friend or foe.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:11
verses.text: And for this reason, the tradition continues, the Creed is not written on paper or parchment, but is retained in the hearts of the faithful, that it may be certain that no one has learnt it by reading, as is sometimes the case with unbelievers, but by tradition from the Apostles.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:12
verses.text: The Apostles therefore, as we have said, being about to separate in order to preach the Gospel, settled upon this sign or token of their agreement in the faith; and, unlike the sons of Noah, who, when they were about to separate from one another, builded a tower of baked bricks and pitch, whose top might reach to heaven, they raised a monument of faith, which might withstand the enemy, composed of living stones and pearls of the Lord, such that neither winds might overthrow it, nor floods undermine it, nor the force of storms and tempests shake it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:13
verses.text: Right justly, then, were the former, when, on the eve of separation, they builded a tower of pride, condemned to the confusion of tongues, so that no one might understand his neighbour's speech; while the latter, who were building a tower of faith, were endowed with the knowledge and understanding of all languages; so that the one might prove a sign and token of sin, the other of faith.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 2:14
verses.text: But it is time now that we should say something about these same pearls, among which is placed first the fountain and source of all, when it is said,—.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:2
verses.text: I Believe in God the Father Almighty.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:3
verses.text: But before I begin to discuss the meaning of the words, I think it well to mention that in different Churches some additions are found in this article.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:4
verses.text: This is not the case, however, in the Church of the city of Rome; the reason being, as I suppose, that, on the one hand, no heresy has had its origin there, and, on the other, that the ancient custom is there kept up, that those who are going to be baptized should rehearse the Creed publicly, that is, in the audience of the people; the consequence of which is that the ears of those who are already believers will not admit the addition of a single word.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:5
verses.text: But in other places, as I understand, additions appear to have been made, on account of certain heretics, by means of which it was hoped that novelty in doctrine would be excluded.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:6
verses.text: We, however, follow that order which we received when we were baptized in the Church of Aquileia.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:7
verses.text: I Believe, therefore, is placed in the forefront, as the Apostle Paul, writing to the Hebrews, says, "He that cometh to God must first of all believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of those who believe on Him".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:8
verses.text: The Prophet also says, "Except ye believe, ye shall not understand".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:9
verses.text: That the way to understand, therefore, may be open to you, you do rightly first of all, in professing that you believe; for no one embarks upon the sea, and trusts himself to the deep and liquid element, unless he first believes it possible that he will have a safe voyage; neither does the husbandman commit his seed to the furrows and scatter his grain on the earth, but in the belief that the showers will come, together with the sun's warmth, through whose fostering influence, aided by favouring winds, the earth will produce and multiply and ripen its fruits.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:10
verses.text: In fine, nothing in life can be transacted if there be not first a readiness to believe.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:11
verses.text: What wonder then, if, coming to God, we first of all profess that we believe, seeing that, without this, not even common life can be lived.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:12
verses.text: We have premised these remarks at the outset, since the Pagans are wont to object to us that our religion, because it lacks reasons, rests solely on belief.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:13
verses.text: We have shewn, therefore, that nothing can possibly be done or remain stable unless belief precede.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:14
verses.text: Finally, marriages are contracted in the belief that children will be born; and children are committed to the care of masters in the belief that the teaching of the masters will be transferred to the pupils; and one man assumes the ensigns of empire, believing that peoples and cities and a well-equipped army also will obey him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 3:15
verses.text: But if no one enters upon any one of these several undertakings except in the belief that the results spoken of will follow, must not belief be much more requisite if one would come to the knowledge of God? But let us see what this "short word" of the Creed sets forth.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:2
verses.text: "I Believe in God the Father Almighty".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:3
verses.text: The Eastern Churches almost universally deliver the article thus, "I believe in One God the Father Almighty;" and again in the next article, where we say, "And in Christ Jesus, His only Son, our Lord," they deliver it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:4
verses.text: , "And in One (Lord) our Lord Jesus Christ, His only Son;" confessing, that is, "one God," and "one Lord," in accordance with the authority of the Apostle Paul.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:5
verses.text: But we shall return to this by-and-by.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:6
verses.text: For the present, let us turn our attention to the words, "In God the Father Almighty".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:7
verses.text: "God," so far as the human mind can form an idea, is the name of that nature or substance which is above all things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:8
verses.text: "Father" is a word expressive of a secret and ineffable mystery.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:9
verses.text: When you hear the word "God," you must understand thereby a substance without beginning, without end, simple, uncompounded, invisible, incorporeal, ineffable, inappreciable, which has in it nothing which has been either added or created.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:10
verses.text: For He is without cause who is absolutely the cause of all things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:11
verses.text: When you hear the word "Father," you must understand by this the Father of a Son, which Son is the image of the aforesaid substance.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:12
verses.text: For as no one is called "Lord" unless he have a possession or a servant whose lord he is, and as no one is called "master" unless he have a disciple, so no one can possibly be called "father" unless he have a son.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:13
verses.text: This very name of "Father," therefore, shews plainly that, together with the Father there subsists a Son also.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:14
verses.text: But I would not have you discuss how God the Father begat the Son, nor intrude too curiously into the profound mystery, lest haply, by prying too eagerly into the brightness of light inaccessible, you should lose the faint glimpse which, by the gift of God, has been vouchsafed to mortals.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:15
verses.text: Or, if you suppose that this is a subject to be investigated with all possible scrutiny, first propose to yourself questions which concern ourselves, and then, if you are able to deal satisfactorily with them, speed on from earthly things to heavenly, from visible to invisible.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:16
verses.text: Determine first, if you can, how the mind, which is within you, generates a word, and what is the spirit of the memory which is in it; and how these, though diverse in reality and in operation, are yet one in substance or nature; and though they proceed from the mind, yet are never separated from it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:17
verses.text: And if these, though they are in us and in the substance of our own soul, yet seem to be hidden from us in proportion as they are invisible to our bodily sight, let us take for our enquiry things which are more open to view.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:18
verses.text: How does a spring generate a river from itself? By what spirit is it borne into a rapidly flowing stream? How happens it that, while the river and the spring are one and inseparable, yet neither can the river be understood to be, or can be called, the spring, nor the spring the river, and yet he who has seen the river has seen the spring also? Exercise yourself first in explaining these, and explain, if you are able, things which you have under your hands; and then you may come to loftier matters.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:19
verses.text: Do not think, however, that I would have you ascend all at once from the earth above the heavens: I would first, with your leave, draw your attention to this firmament which our eyes behold, and ask you to explain, if you can, the nature of this visible luminary,—how that celestial fire generates from itself the brightness of light, how it also produces heat; and though these are three in reality, how they are yet one in substance.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:20
verses.text: And if you are capable of investigating each of these, even then you must acknowledge that the mystery of the Divine generation is by so much the more diverse and the more transcendent as the Creator is more powerful than the creatures, as the artificer is more excellent than his work, as He who ever is more noble than that which had its beginning out of nothing.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:21
verses.text: That God then is the Father of His only Son our Lord is to be believed, not discussed; for it is not lawful for a servant to dispute about the nativity of his lord.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:22
verses.text: The Father hath borne witness from heaven, saying, "This is My beloved Son, in Whom I am well pleased: hear Him".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:23
verses.text: The Father saith that He is His Son and bids us hear Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:24
verses.text: The Son saith, "He who seeth Me seeth the Father also," and "I and the Father are one," and "I came forth from God and am come into the world".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 4:25
verses.text: Where is the man who can thrust himself as a disputant between these words of Father and Son, who can divide the Godhead, separate its volition, break asunder the substance, cut the spirit in parts, and deny that what the Truth speaks is true? God then is a true Father as the Father of the Truth, not begetting extrinsically, but generating the Son from that which Himself is; that is, as the All-wise He generates Wisdom, as the Just Justice, as the Everlasting the Everlasting, as the Immortal Immortality, as the Invisible the Invisible; because He is Light, He generates Brightness, because He is Mind, He generates the Word.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:2
verses.text: Now whereas we said that the Eastern Churches, in their delivery of the Creed, say, "In one God the Father Almighty," and "in one Lord," the "one" is not to be understood numerically but absolutely.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:3
verses.text: For example, if one should say, "one man" or "one horse," here "one" is used numerically.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:4
verses.text: For there may be a second man and a third, or a second horse and a third.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:5
verses.text: But where a second or a third cannot be added, if we say "one" we mean one not numerically but absolutely.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:6
verses.text: For example, if we say, "one Sun," here the meaning is that a second or a third cannot be added, for there is but one Sun.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:7
verses.text: Much more then is God, when He is said to be "one," called "one," not numerically but absolutely, that is, He is therefore said to be one because there is no other.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:8
verses.text: In like manner, also, it is to be understood of the Lord, that He is one Lord, Jesus Christ, by or through Whom God the Father possesses dominion over all, whence also, in the next clause, God is called "Almighty".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:9
verses.text: God is called Almighty because He possesses rule and dominion over all things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:10
verses.text: But the Father possesses all things by His Son, as the Apostle says, "By Him were created all things, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:11
verses.text: And again, writing to the Hebrews, he says, "By Him also He made the worlds," and "He appointed Him heir of all things".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:12
verses.text: By "appointed" we are to understand "generated".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:13
verses.text: Now if the Father made the worlds by Him, and all things were created by Him, and He is heir of all things, then by Him He possesses rule also over all things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:14
verses.text: Because, as light is born of light, and truth of truth, so Almighty is born of Almighty.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:15
verses.text: As it is written of the Seraphim in the Revelation of John, "And they have no rest day and night, crying Holy, Holy, Holy, Lord God of Sabaoth, which was and which is and which is to come, the Almighty".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:16
verses.text: He then who "is to come" is called "Almighty".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:17
verses.text: And what other is there who "is to come" but Christ, the Son of God?  To the foregoing is added "Invisible and Impassible".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:18
verses.text: I should mention that these two words are not in the Creed of the Roman Church.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:19
verses.text: They were added in our Church, as is well known, on account of the Sabellian heresy, called by us "the Patripassian," that, namely, which says that the Father Himself was born of the Virgin and became visible, or affirms that He suffered in the flesh.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:20
verses.text: To exclude such impiety, therefore, concerning the Father, our forefathers seem to have added these words, calling the Father "invisible and impassible".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:21
verses.text: For it is evident that the Son, not the Father, became incarnate and was born in the flesh, and that from that nativity in the flesh the Son became "visible and passible".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:22
verses.text: Yet so far as regards that immortal substance of the Godhead, which He possesses, and which is one and the same with that of the Father, we must believe that neither the Father, nor the Son, nor the Holy Ghost is "visible or passible".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:23
verses.text: But the Son, in that He condescended to assume flesh, was both seen and also suffered in the flesh.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:24
verses.text: Which also the Prophet foretold when he said, "This is our God: no other shall be accounted of in comparison of Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:25
verses.text: He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob His servant and to Israel His beloved.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 5:26
verses.text: Afterward He shewed Himself upon the earth, and conversed with men".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:2
verses.text: Next there follows, "And in Christ Jesus, His Only Son, Our Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:3
verses.text: "Jesus" is a Hebrew word meaning "Saviour".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:4
verses.text: "Christ" is so called from "Chrism," i-e: unction.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:5
verses.text: For we read in the Books of Moses, that Auses, the son of Nave, when he was chosen to lead the people, had his name changed from "Auses" to "Jesus," to shew that this was a name proper for princes and generals, for those, namely, who should "save" the people who followed them.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:6
verses.text: Therefore, both were called "Jesus," both the one who conducted the people, who had been brought forth out of the land of Egypt, and freed from the wanderings of the wilderness, into the land of promise, and the other, who conducted the people, who had been brought forth from the darkness of ignorance, and recalled from the errors of the world, into the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:7
verses.text: "Christ" is a name proper either to High Priests or Kings.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:8
verses.text: For formerly both high priests and kings were consecrated with the ointment of chrism: but these, as mortal and corruptible, with material and corruptible ointment.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:9
verses.text: Jesus is made Christ, being anointed with the Holy Spirit, as the Scripture saith of Him "Whom the Father hath anointed with the Holy Spirit sent down from heaven".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:10
verses.text: And Isaiah had prefigured the same, saying in the person of the Son, "The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me, because He hath anointed Me, He hath sent Me to preach good tidings to the poor".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:11
verses.text: Having shewn them what "Jesus" is, Who saves His people, and what "Christ" is, Who is made a High Priest for ever, let us now see in what follows, of Whom these things are said, "His only Son, our Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:12
verses.text: Here we are taught that this Jesus, of whom we have spoken, and this Christ, the meaning of whose name we have expounded, is "the only Son of God" and "our Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:13
verses.text: Lest, perchance, you should think that these human names have an earthly significance, therefore it is added that He is "the only Son of God, our Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:14
verses.text: For He is born One of One, because there is one brightness of light, and there is one word of the understanding.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:15
verses.text: Neither does an incorporeal generation degenerate into the plural number, or suffer division, where He Who is born is in no wise separated from Him Who begets.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:16
verses.text: He is "only" (unique), as thought is to the mind, as wisdom is to the wise, as a word is to the understanding, as valour is to the brave.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:17
verses.text: For as the Father is said by the Apostle to be "alone wise," so likewise the Son alone is called wisdom.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:18
verses.text: He is then the "only Son".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:19
verses.text: And, although in glory, everlastingness, virtue, dominion, power, He is what the Father is, yet all these He hath not unoriginately as the Father, but from the Father, as the Son, without beginning and equal; and although He is the Head of all things, yet the Father is the Head of Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 6:20
verses.text: For so it is written, "The Head of Christ is God".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:2
verses.text: When you hear the word "Son," you must not think of a nativity after the flesh; but remember that it is spoken of an incorporeal substance, and a simple and uncompounded nature.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:3
verses.text: For if, as we said above, whether when the understanding generates a word, or the mind sense, or light brings forth brightness from itself, nothing of this sort is sought for, or any manner of weakness and imperfection imagined in this kind of generation, how much purer and more sacred ought to be our conception of the Creator of all these!  But perhaps you say, "The generation of which you speak is an unsubstantial generation.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:4
verses.text: For light does not produce substantial brightness, nor the understanding generate a substantial word, but the Son of God, it is affirmed, was generated substantially".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:5
verses.text: To this we reply, first, When in other things examples or illustrations are used, the resemblance cannot hold in every particular, but only in some one point for which the illustration is employed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:6
verses.text: For instance, When it is said in the Gospel, "The kingdom of heaven is like leaven, which a woman hid in three measures of meal," are we to imagine that the kingdom of heaven is in all respects like leaven, so that like leaven it is palpable and perishable so as to become sour and unfit for use? Obviously the illustration was employed simply for this object—to shew how, through the preaching of God's word which seems so small a thing, men's minds could be imbued with the leaven of faith.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:7
verses.text: So likewise, when it is said, "The kingdom of heaven is like unto a net cast into the sea, which draws in fishes of every kind," are we to suppose that the substance of the kingdom of heaven is likened in all respects to the nature of twine of which a net is made, and to the knots with which the meshes are tied? No; the sole object of the comparison is to shew that, as a net brings fishes to the shore from the depths of the sea, so by the preaching of the kingdom of heaven men's souls are liberated from the depth of the error of this world.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:8
verses.text: From whence it is evident that examples or illustrations do not answer in every particular to the things which they are brought to exemplify or illustrate.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 7:9
verses.text: Otherwise, if they were the same in all respects, they would no longer be called examples or illustrations, but rather would be the things themselves.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:2
verses.text: Then further it is to be observed that no creature can be such as its Creator.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:3
verses.text: And therefore, as the divine substance or essence admits of no comparison, so neither does the Divinity.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:4
verses.text: Moreover, every creature is of nothing.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:5
verses.text: If therefore a spark which is so unsubstantial but yet is fire, begets of itself a creature which is of nothing, and maintains in it the essential nature of that from which it springs, (i-e: the fire of the parent spark), why could not the substance of that eternal Light which ever has been because it has in itself nothing which is not substantial, produce from itself substantial brightness? Rightly, therefore, is the Son called "only," "unique".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:6
verses.text: For He who hath been so born is "only" and "unique".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:7
verses.text: That which is unique can admit of no comparison.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:8
verses.text: Nor can He who made all things be like in substance to the things which He has made.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:9
verses.text: This then is Christ Jesus, the only Son of God, who is also our Lord.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:10
verses.text: "Only" may be referred both to Son and to Lord.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:11
verses.text: For Jesus Christ is "only" both as truly Son and as one Lord.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:12
verses.text: For all other sons, though they are called sons, are so called by the grace of adoption, not by verity of nature; and if there be others who are called lords, they are called so from an authority bestowed not inherent.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:13
verses.text: But Christ alone is the only Son and the only Lord, as the Apostle saith, "One Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom are all things".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:14
verses.text: Therefore, after the Creed has in due order set forth the ineffable mystery of the nativity of the Son from the Father, it now descends to the dispensation which He vouchsafed to enter upon for man's salvation.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 8:15
verses.text: And of Him whom just now it called the "only Son of God" and "our Lord," it now says.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:2
verses.text: "Who Was Born by (de) The Holy Ghost of the Virgin Mary".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:3
verses.text: This nativity among men is in the way of dispensation, whereas the former nativity is of the divine substance; the one results from his condescension, the other from his essential nature.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:4
verses.text: He is born by the Holy Ghost of the Virgin.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:5
verses.text: Here a chaste ear and a pure mind is required.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:6
verses.text: For you must understand that now a temple hath been built within the secret recesses of a Virgin's womb for Him of Whom erewhile you learnt that He was born ineffably of the Father.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:7
verses.text: And just as in the sanctification of the Holy Ghost no thought of imperfection is to be admitted, so in the Virgin-birth no defilement is to be imagined.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:8
verses.text: For this birth was a new birth given to this world, and rightly new.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:9
verses.text: For He Who is the only Son in heaven is by consequence the only Son on earth, and was uniquely born, born as no other ever was or can be.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:10
verses.text: The words of the Prophets concerning Him, "A Virgin shall conceive and bring forth a Son," are known to all, and are cited in the Gospels again and again.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:11
verses.text: The Prophet Ezekiel too had predicted the miraculous manner of that birth, calling Mary figuratively "the Gate of the Lord," the gate, namely, through which the Lord entered the world.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:12
verses.text: For he saith, "The gate which looks towards the East shall be closed, and shall not be opened, and no one shall pass through it, because the Lord God of Israel shall pass through it, and it shall be closed".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:13
verses.text: What could be said with such evident reference to the inviolate preservation of the Virgin's condition? That Gate of Virginity was closed; through it the Lord God of Israel entered; through it He came forth from the Virgin's womb into this world; and the Virgin-state being preserved inviolate, the gate of the Virgin remained closed for ever.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 9:14
verses.text: Therefore the Holy Ghost is spoken of as the Creator of the Lord's flesh and of His temple.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:2
verses.text: Starting from this point you may understand the majesty of the Holy Ghost also.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:3
verses.text: For the Gospel witnesses of Him that when the angel said to the Virgin, "Thou shalt bring forth a Son and shalt call His name Jesus, for He shall save His people from their sins," she replied, "How shall this be, seeing I know not a man?" on which the angel said to her, "The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:4
verses.text: Wherefore that holy Thing which shall be born of Thee shall be called the Son of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:5
verses.text: See here the Trinity mutually cooperating with each other.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:6
verses.text: The Holy Ghost is spoken of as coming upon the Virgin, and the Power of the Highest as overshadowing her.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:7
verses.text: What is the Power of the Highest but Christ Himself, Who is the Power of God and the Wisdom of God? Whose is this Power? The Power of the Highest.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:8
verses.text: There is here then the Highest, there is also the Power of the Highest, there is also the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:9
verses.text: This is the Trinity, everywhere latent, and everywhere apparent, distinct in names and persons, but inseparable in the substance of the Godhead.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 10:10
verses.text: And although the Son alone is born of the Virgin, yet there is present also the Highest, there is present also the Holy Ghost, that both the conception and the bringing forth of the Virgin may be sanctified.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:2
verses.text: These things, since they are asserted upon the warrant of the Prophetical Scriptures, may possibly silence the Jews, infidel and incredulous though they be.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:3
verses.text: But the Pagans are wont to ridicule us when they hear us speak of a Virgin-birth.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:4
verses.text: We must, therefore, say a few words in reply to their cavils.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:5
verses.text: Every birth, I suppose, depends upon three conditions.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:6
verses.text: There must be a woman of mature age, she must have intercourse with a man, her womb must not be barren.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:7
verses.text: Of these three conditions, in the birth of which we are speaking, one was wanting, the man.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:8
verses.text: And this, forasmuch as He of Whose birth we speak was not an earthly but a heavenly man, was supplied by the Heavenly Spirit, the virginity of the mother being preserved inviolate.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:9
verses.text: And yet why should it be thought marvellous for a virgin to conceive, when it is well known that the Eastern bird, which they call the Phoenix, is in such wise born, or born again, without the intervention of a mate, that it remains continually one, and continually by being born or born again succeeds itself? That bees know no wedlock, and no bringing forth of young, is notorious.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:10
verses.text: There are also other things which are found to be subject to some such law of birth.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:11
verses.text: Shall it be thought incredible, then, that was done by divine power, for the renewal and restoration of the whole world, of which instances are observed in the nativity of animals? And yet it is strange that the Gentiles should think this impossible, who believe their own Minerva to have been born from the brain of Jupiter.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:12
verses.text: What is more difficult to believe, or what more contrary to nature? Here, there is a woman, the order of nature is kept, there is conception, and in due time birth; there, there is no female, but a man alone, and—birth! Why does he who believes the one marvel at the other? Again, they say that Father Bacchus was born from Jupiter's thigh.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:13
verses.text: Here is another portent, yet it is believed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:14
verses.text: Venus also, whom they call Aphrodite, was born, they believe, of the foam of the sea, as her compounded name shews.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:15
verses.text: They affirm that Castor and Pollux were born of an egg, the Myrmidons of ants.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:16
verses.text: There are a thousand other things which, though contrary to nature, find credit with them, such as the stones thrown by Deucalion and Pyrrha, and the crop of men sprung from thence.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 11:17
verses.text: And when they believe such myths and so many of them, does one thing seem impossible to them, that a woman of mature age, not defiled by man but impregnated by the Holy Ghost, should conceive a divine progeny? who, forsooth, if they are hard of belief, ought in no wise to have given credence to those prodigies, being, as they are, so many and so degrading; but if they do believe them, they ought much more readily to receive these beliefs of ours, so honourable and so holy, than theirs so discreditable and so vile.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:2
verses.text: But they say, perhaps, If it was possible to God that a virgin should conceive, it was possible also that she should bring forth, but they think it unmeet that a being of so great majesty should enter the world in such wise, that even though there had been no defilement from intercourse with man, there should yet be the unseemliness attendant upon the act of delivery.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:3
verses.text: To which let us reply briefly, meeting them on their own level.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:4
verses.text: If a person should see a little child in the act of being suffocated in a quagmire, and himself, a great man and powerful, should go into the mire, just at its verge, so to say, to rescue the dying child; would you blame this man as defiled for having stepped into a little mire, or would you praise him as merciful, for having preserved the life of one that was perishing? But the case supposed is that of an ordinary man.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:5
verses.text: Let us return to the nature of Him Who was born.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:6
verses.text: How much, think you, is the nature of the Sun inferior to him? How much beyond doubt, the Creature to the Creator? Consider now if a ray of the sun alights upon a quagmire, does it receive any pollution from it? or is the sun the worse for shedding his light upon foul objects? Fire, too, how far inferior is its nature to the things of which we are speaking? Yet no substance, whether foul or vile, is believed to pollute fire if applied to it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:7
verses.text: When the case is plainly thus with regard to material things, do you suppose that aught of pollution and defilement can befall that supereminent and incorporeal nature, which is above all fire and all light? Then, lastly, note this also: we say that man was created by God out of the clay of the earth.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:8
verses.text: But if God is thought to be defiled in seeking to recover His own work, much more must He be thought so in making that work originally.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:9
verses.text: And it is idle to ask why He passed through what is repugnant to our sense of modesty, when you cannot tell why He made what is so repugnant.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:10
verses.text: And therefore it is not nature but general estimation that has made us think these things to be such.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 12:11
verses.text: Otherwise, all things that are in the body, being formed from one and the same clay, are distinguished from one another only in their uses and natural offices.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:2
verses.text: But there is another consideration which we must not leave out in the solution of this question, namely, that the substance of God, which is wholly incorporeal, cannot be introduced into bodies or be received by them in the first instance, unless there be some spiritual substance as a medium, which is capable of receiving the divine Spirit.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:3
verses.text: For instance, if we say that light is able to irradiate all the members of the body, yet by none of them can it be received except by the eye.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:4
verses.text: For it is the eye alone which is receptive of light.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:5
verses.text: So the Son of God is born of a virgin, not associated with the flesh alone in the first instance, but begotten with a soul as a medium between the flesh and God.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:6
verses.text: With the soul, then, serving as a medium, and receiving the Word of God in the secret citadel of the rational spirit, God was born of the Virgin without any such disparagement as you imagine.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:7
verses.text: And therefore nothing is to be esteemed base or unseemly wherein was the sanctification of the Spirit, and where the soul which was capable of God became also a partaker of flesh.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:8
verses.text: Account nothing impossible where the power of the Most High was present.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 13:9
verses.text: Have no thought of human weakness where there was the plenitude of Divinity.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:2
verses.text: He Was Crucified Under Pontius Pilate and Was Buried: He Descended into Hell.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:3
verses.text: The Apostle Paul teaches us that we ought to have "the eyes of our understanding enlightened" "that we may understand what is the height and breadth and depth".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:4
verses.text: "The height and breadth and depth" is a description of the Cross, of which that part which is fixed in the earth he calls the depth, the height that which is erected upon the earth and reaches upward, the breadth that which is spread out to the right hand and to the left.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:5
verses.text: Since, therefore, there are so many kinds of death by which it is given to men to depart this life, why does the Apostle wish us to have our understanding enlightened so as to know the reason why, of all of them, the Cross was chosen in preference for the death of the Saviour.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:6
verses.text: We must know, then, that that Cross was a triumph.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:7
verses.text: It was a signal trophy.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:8
verses.text: A triumph is a token of victory over an enemy.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:9
verses.text: Since then Christ, when He came, brought three kingdoms at once into subjection under His sway (for this He signifies when he says, "That in the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things on earth, and things under the earth"), and conquered all of these by His death, a death was sought answerable to the mystery, so that being lifted up in the air, and subduing the powers of the air, He might make a display of His victory over these supernatural and celestial powers.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 14:10
verses.text: Moreover the holy Prophet says that "all the day long He stretched out His hands" to the people on the earth, that He might both make protestation to unbelievers and invite believers: finally, by that part which is sunk under the earth, He signified His bringing into subjection to Himself the kingdoms of the nether world.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:2
verses.text: Moreover,—to touch briefly some of the more recondite topics,—when God made the world in the beginning, He set over it and appointed certain powers of celestial virtues by whom the race of mortal men might be governed and directed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:3
verses.text: That this was so done Moses signifies in the Song in Deuteronomy, "When the Most High divided the nations, He appointed the bounds of the nations according to the number of the angels of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:4
verses.text: But some of these, as he who is called the Prince of this world, did not exercise the power which God had committed to them according to the laws by which they had received it, nor did they teach mankind to obey God's commandments, but taught them rather to follow their own perverse guidance.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:5
verses.text: Thus we were brought under the bonds of sin, because, as the Prophet saith, "We were sold under our sins".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:6
verses.text: For every man, when he yields to lust, is receiving the purchase-money of his soul.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:7
verses.text: Under that bond then every man was held by those most wicked rulers, which same bond Christ, when He came, tore down and stripped them of this their power.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:8
verses.text: This Paul signifies under a great mystery, when he says of Him, "He destroyed the hand-writing which was against us, nailing it to His cross, and led away principalities and powers, triumphing over them in Himself".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:9
verses.text: Those rulers, then, whom God had set over mankind, having become contumacious and tyrannical, took in hand to assail the men who had been committed to their charge and to rout them utterly in the conflicts of sin, as the Prophet Ezekiel mystically intimates when he says, "In that day angels shall come forth hastening to exterminate Ethiopia, and there shall be perturbation among them in the day of Egypt; for behold He comes".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:10
verses.text: Having stript them then of their almighty power, Christ is said to have triumphed, and to have delivered to men the power which was taken from them, as also Himself saith to His disciples in the Gospel, "Behold I have given you power to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and upon all the might of the enemy".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:11
verses.text: The Cross of Christ, then, brought those who had wrongfully abused the authority which they had received into subjection to those who had before been in subjection to them.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:12
verses.text: But us, that is, mankind, it teaches first of all to resist sin even unto death, and willingly to die for the sake of religion.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:13
verses.text: Next, this same Cross sets before us an example of obedience, in like manner as it hath punished the contumacy of those who were once our rulers.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:14
verses.text: Hear, therefore, how the Apostle would teach us obedience by the Cross of Christ: "Let this mind be in you, which was in Christ Jesus, Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God, but made Himself of no reputation, taking upon Him the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men; and, being found in fashion as a man, He became obedient unto death, even the death of the Cross".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 15:15
verses.text: As, then, a consummate master teaches both by example and precept, so Christ taught the obedience, which good men are to render even at the cost of death, by Himself first dying in rendering it.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:2
verses.text: But perhaps some one is alarmed at hearing us discourse of the death of Him of Whom, a short while since, we said that He is everlasting with God the Father, and that He was begotten of the Father's substance, and is one with God the Father, in dominion, majesty, and eternity.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:3
verses.text: But be not alarmed, O faithful hearer.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:4
verses.text: Presently thou wilt see Him of Whose death thou hearest once more immortal; for the death to which He submits is about to spoil death.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:5
verses.text: For the object of that mystery of the Incarnation which we expounded just now was that the divine virtue of the Son of God, as though it were a hook concealed beneath the form and fashion of human flesh (He being, as the Apostle Paul says, "found in fashion as a man"), might lure on the Prince of this world to a conflict, to whom offering His flesh as a bait, His divinity underneath might catch him and hold him fast with its hook, through the shedding of His immaculate blood.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:6
verses.text: For He alone Who knows no stain of sin hath destroyed the sins of all, of those, at least, who have marked the door-posts of their faith with His blood.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:7
verses.text: As, therefore, if a fish seizes a baited hook, it not only does not take the bait off the hook, but is drawn out of the water to be itself food for others, so He Who had the power of death seized the body of Jesus in death, not being aware of the hook of Divinity inclosed within it, but having swallowed it he was caught forthwith, and the bars of hell being burst asunder, he was drawn forth as it were from the abyss to become food for others.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:8
verses.text: Which result the Prophet Ezekiel long ago foretold under this same figure, saying, "I will draw thee out with My hook, and stretch thee out upon the earth: the plains shall be filled with thee, and I will set all the fowls of the air over thee, and I will satiate all the beasts of the earth with thee".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:9
verses.text: The Prophet David also says, "Thou hast broken the heads of the great dragon, Thou hast given him to be meat to the people of Ethiopia".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 16:10
verses.text: And Job in like manner witnesses of the same mystery, for he says in the person of the Lord speaking to him, "Wilt thou draw forth the dragon with a hook, and wilt thou put thy bit in his nostrils?".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17:2
verses.text: It is with no loss or disparagement therefore of His Divine nature that Christ suffers in the flesh, but His Divine nature through the flesh descended into death, that by the infirmity of the flesh He might effect salvation; not that He might be detained by death according to the law of mortality, but that He might by Himself in his resurrection open the gates of death.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17:3
verses.text: It is as if a king were to proceed to a prison, and to go in and open the doors, undo the fetters, break in pieces the chains, the bars, and the bolts, and bring forth and set at liberty the prisoners, and restore those who are sitting in darkness and in the shadow of death to light and life.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17:4
verses.text: The king, therefore, is said indeed to have been in prison, but not under the same condition as the prisoners who were detained there.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 17:5
verses.text: They were in prison to be punished, He to free them from punishment.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:2
verses.text: They who have handed down the Creed to us have with much forethought specified the time when these things were done—"under Pontius Pilate,"—lest in any respect the tradition should falter, as though vague and uncertain.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:3
verses.text: But it should be known that the clause, "He descended into Hell," is not added in the Creed of the Roman Church, neither is it in that of the Oriental Churches.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:4
verses.text: It seems to be implied, however, when it is said that "He was buried".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:5
verses.text: But in the love and zeal for the Divine Scriptures which possess you, you say to me, I doubt not, "These things ought to be proved by more evident testimonies from the Divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:6
verses.text: For the more important the things are which are to be believed, so much the more do they need apt and undoubted witness".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:7
verses.text: True.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:8
verses.text: But we, as speaking to those who know the law, have left unnoticed, for the sake of brevity, a whole forest of testimonies.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 18:9
verses.text: But if this also be required, let us cite a few out of many, knowing, as we do, that to those who are acquainted with the Scriptures, a very ample sea of testimonies lies open.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:2
verses.text: First of all, then, we must know that the doctrine of the Cross is not regarded by all in the same light.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:3
verses.text: It is one thing to the Gentiles, to the Jews another, to Christians another; as also the Apostle says, "We preach Christ crucified,—to the Jews a stumbling-block, to the Gentiles foolishness, but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ, the power of God and the wisdom of God;" and, in the same place, "For the preaching of the Cross is to those who perish foolishness, but to those who are saved," that is, to us, it is "the Power of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:4
verses.text: The Jews, to whom it had been delivered out of the Law, that Christ should abide for ever, were offended by His Cross, because they were unwilling to believe His resurrection.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:5
verses.text: To the Gentiles it seemed foolishness that God should have submitted to death, because they were ignorant of the mystery of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:6
verses.text: But Christians, who had accepted His birth and passion in the flesh and His resurrection from the dead, of course believed that it was the power of God which had overcome death.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:7
verses.text: First, therefore, hear how this very thing is prophetically declared by Isaiah, that the Jews, to whom the Prophets had foretold these things, would not believe, but that they who had never heard them from the Prophets, would believe them.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:8
verses.text: "To whom He was not spoken of they shall see, and they that have not heard shall understand".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:9
verses.text: Moreover, this same Isaiah foretells that, while those who were engaged in the study of the Law from childhood to old age believed not, to the Gentiles every mystery should be transferred.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:10
verses.text: His words are: "And the Lord of Hosts shall make a feast on this mountain unto all nations: they shall drink joy, they shall drink wine, they shall be anointed with ointment on this mountain.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:11
verses.text: Deliver all these things to the nations".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:12
verses.text: This was the counsel of the Almighty respecting all the nations.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:13
verses.text: But they who boast themselves of their knowledge of the Law will, perhaps, say to us, "You blaspheme in saying that the Lord was subjected to the corruption of death and to the suffering of the Cross".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:14
verses.text: Read, therefore, what you find written in the Lamentations of Jeremiah: "The Spirit of our countenance, Christ the Lord, was taken in our corruptions, of whom we said, we shall live under His shadow among the nations".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:15
verses.text: Thou hearest how the Prophet says that Christ the Lord was taken, and for us, that is, for our sins, delivered to corruption.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 19:16
verses.text: Under whose shadow, since the people of the Jews have continued in unbelief, he says the Gentiles lie, because we live not in Israel, but among the Gentiles.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:2
verses.text: But, if it does not weary you, let the point out as briefly as possible, specific references to prophecy in the Gospels, that those who are being instructed in the first elements of the faith may have these testimonies written on their hearts, lest any doubt concerning the things which they believe should at any time take them by surprise.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:3
verses.text: We are told in the Gospel that Judas, one of Christ's friends and associates at table, betrayed Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:4
verses.text: Let the show you how this is foretold in the Psalms: "He who hath eaten My bread hath lifted up his heel against Me:" and in another place; "My friends and My neighbours drew near and set themselves against Me:" and again; "His words were made softer than oil and yet be they very darts".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:5
verses.text: What then is meant by his words were made soft? "Judas came to Jesus and said unto Him, Hail, Master, and kissed Him".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:6
verses.text: Thus through the soft blandishment of a kiss he implanted the execrable dart of betrayal.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:7
verses.text: On which the Lord said to him, "Judas, betrayest thou the Son of Man with a kiss?" You observe that He was appraised by the traitor's covetousness at thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:8
verses.text: Of this also the Prophet speaks, "And I said unto them, If ye think good, give me my price, or if not, forbear;" and presently, "I received from them," he says, "thirty pieces of silver, and I cast them into the house of the Lord, into the foundry".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:9
verses.text: Is not this what is written in the Gospels, that Judas, "repenting of what he had done, brought back the money, and threw it down in the temple and departed?" Well did He call it His price, as though blaming and upbraiding.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:10
verses.text: For He had done so many good works among them, He had given sight to the blind, feet to the lame, the power of walking to the palsied, life also to the dead; for all these good works they paid Him death as His price, appraised at thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:11
verses.text: It is related also in the Gospels that He was bound.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 20:12
verses.text: This also the word of prophecy had foretold by Isaiah, saying, "Woe unto their soul, who have devised a most evil device against themselves, saying, Let us bind the just One, seeing that He is unprofitable to us".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:2
verses.text: But, says some one, "Are these things to be understood of the Lord? Could the Lord be held prisoner by men and dragged to judgment?" Of this also the same Prophet shall convince you.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:3
verses.text: For he says, "The Lord Himself shall come into judgment with the elders and princes of the people".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:4
verses.text: The Lord is judged then according to the Prophet's testimony, and not only judged, but scourged, and smitten on the face with the palms (of men's hands), and spitted on, and suffers every insult and indignity for our sake.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:5
verses.text: And because all who should hear these things preached by the Apostles would be perfectly amazed, therefore also the Prophet speaking in their person exclaims, "Lord, who hath believed our report?" For it is incredible that God, the Son of God, should be spoken of and preached as having suffered these things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:6
verses.text: For this reason they are foretold by the Prophets, lest any doubt should spring up in those who are about to believe.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:7
verses.text: Christ the Lord Himself therefore in His own person, says, "I gave My back to the scourges, and My cheeks to the palms, I turned not away My face from shame and spitting".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:8
verses.text: This also is written among His other sufferings, that they bound Him, and led Him away to Pilate.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:9
verses.text: This also the Prophet foretold, saying, "And they bound him and conducted Him as a pledge of friendship (xenium) to King Jarim".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:10
verses.text: But some one objects, "But Pilate was not a king".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:11
verses.text: Hear then what the Gospel relates next, "Pilate hearing that He was from Galilee, sent Him to Herod, who was king in Israel at that time".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:12
verses.text: And rightly does the Prophet add the name "Jarim," which means "a wild-vine, for Herod was not of the house of Israel, nor of that Israelitish vine which the Lord had brought out of Egypt, and "planted in a very fruitful hill," but was a wild vine, i-e: of an alien stock.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:13
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, was he called "a wild-vine," because he in nowise sprung from the shoots of the vine of Israel.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:14
verses.text: And whereas the Prophet used the phrase "xenium," "A pledge of friendship," this also corresponds, "For Herod and Pilate," as the Gospel witnesses, "from being enemies were made friends," and, as though in token of their reconciliation, each sent Jesus bound to the other.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 21:15
verses.text: What matter, so long as Jesus, as Saviour, reconciles those who were at variance, and restores peace, and also brings back concord! Wherefore of this also it is written in Job, "May the Lord reconcile the hearts of the princes of the earth".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:2
verses.text: It is related that when Pilate would fain have released Him all the people cried out, "Crucify Him, Crucify Him!" This also the Prophet Jeremiah foretells, saying, in the person of the Lord Himself, "My inheritance is become to Me as a lion in the forest.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:3
verses.text: He hath uttered his voice against Me, wherefore I have hated it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:4
verses.text: And therefore (saith He) I have forsaken and left My house".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:5
verses.text: And again in another place, "Against whom have ye opened your mouth, and against whom have ye let loose your tongues?" When He stood before His judge, it is written that "He held His peace".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:6
verses.text: Many Scriptures testify of this.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:7
verses.text: In the Psalms it is written, "I became as a man that heareth not, and in whose mouth are no reproofs".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:8
verses.text: And again, "I was as a deaf man, and heard not, and as one that is dumb and openeth not his mouth".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:9
verses.text: And again another Prophet saith, "As a lamb before her shearer, so He opened not His mouth.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:10
verses.text: In His humiliation His judgment was taken away".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:11
verses.text: It is written that there was put on Him a crown of thorns.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:12
verses.text: Of this hear in the Canticles the voice of God the Father marvelling at the iniquity of Jerusalem in the insult done to His Son: "Go forth and see, ye daughters of Jerusalem, the crown wherewith His mother hath crowned Him".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:13
verses.text: Moreover, of the thorns another Prophet makes mention: "I looked that she should bring forth grapes, and she brought forth thorns, and instead of righteousness a cry".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:14
verses.text: But that thou mayest know the secrets of the mystery, it behoved Him, Who came to take away the sins of the world, to free the earth also from the curse, which it had received through the sin of the first man, when the Lord said "Cursed be the earth in thy labours: thorns: and thistles shall it bring forth to thee".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:15
verses.text: For this cause, therefore, is Jesus crowned with thorns, that first sentence of condemnation might be remitted.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:16
verses.text: He is led to the cross, and the life of the whole word is suspended on the wood of which it is made.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:17
verses.text: I would point out how this also is confirmed by testimony from the Prophets.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:18
verses.text: You find Jeremiah speaking of it thus, "Come and let us cast wood into His bread, and crush Him out of the land of the living".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:19
verses.text: And again, Moses, mourning over them, says, "Thy life shall be suspended before thine eyes, and thou shalt fear day and night, and shalt not believe thy life".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:20
verses.text: But we must pass on, for already we are exceeding our proposed measure of brevity, and are lengthening out our "short word" by a long dissertation.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 22:21
verses.text: Yet we will add a few words more, lest we should seem altogether to have passed over what we undertook.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:2
verses.text: It is written that when the side of Jesus was pierced "He shed thereout blood and water".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:3
verses.text: This has a mystical meaning.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:4
verses.text: For Himself had said, "Out of His belly shall flow rivers of living water".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:5
verses.text: But He shed forth blood also, of which the Jews sought that it might be upon themselves and upon their children.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:6
verses.text: He shed forth water, therefore, which might wash believers; He shed forth blood also which might condemn unbelievers.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:7
verses.text: Yet it might be understood also as prefiguring the twofold grace of baptism, one that which is given by the baptism of water, the other that which is sought through martyrdom in the outpouring of blood, for both are called baptism.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:8
verses.text: But if you ask further why our Lord is said to have poured forth blood and water from His side rather than from any other member, I imagine that by the rib in the side the woman is signified.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 23:9
verses.text: Since the fountain of sin and death proceeded from the first woman, who was the rib of the first Adam, the fountain of redemption and life is drawn from the rib of the second Adam.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:2
verses.text: It is written that in our Lord's passion there was darkness over the earth from the sixth hour until the ninth.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:3
verses.text: To this also you will find the Prophet witnessing, "Thy Sun shall go down at mid-day".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:4
