verses.text: And again, the Prophet Zechariah, "In that day there shall be no more light.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:5
verses.text: There shall be cold and frost in one day, and that day known to the Lord; and it shall be neither day nor night, but at evening time there shall be light".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:6
verses.text: What plainer language could the Prophet have used for his words to seem not so much a prophecy of the future as a narrative of the past? He foretold both the cold and the frost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:7
verses.text: For Peter was warming himself at the fire because it was cold: and he was suffering cold not only in respect of the time (the early hour), but also of his faith.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:8
verses.text: There is added, "and that day shall be known to the Lord; and it shall be neither day nor night".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:9
verses.text: What is "neither day nor night?" Did he not plainly speak of the darkness interposed in the day, and then the light afterwards restored? That was not day, for it did not begin with sun-rise, neither was it complete night, for it did not, when the day was ended, receive its due space from the beginning or prolong it to the end; but the light which had been driven away by the crime of wicked men is restored at evening time.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:10
verses.text: For after the ninth hour, the darkness is driven away, and the sun is restored to the world.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 24:11
verses.text: Again, another Prophet witnesses of the same, "The light shall be darkened upon the earth in the day-time".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:2
verses.text: The Gospel further relates that the soldiers parted the garments of Jesus among themselves, and cast lots upon His vesture.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:3
verses.text: The Holy Spirit provided that this also should be witnessed beforehand by the Prophets, for David says, "They parted my garments among them, and upon my vesture they did cast lots".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:4
verses.text: Nor were the Prophets silent even as to the robe, the scarlet robe, which the soldiers are said to have put upon Him in mockery.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:5
verses.text: Listen to Isaiah, "Who is this that cometh from Edom, red in his garments from Bozrah? Wherefore are thy garments red, and thy raiment as though thou hadst trodden in the wine-press?" To which Himself replies, "I have trodden the wine-press alone, O daughter of Sion".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:6
verses.text: For He alone it is Who hath not sinned, and hath taken away the sins of the world.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 25:7
verses.text: For if by one man death could enter into the world, how much more by one man, Who was God also, could life be restored!.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:2
verses.text: It is related also that vinegar was given Him to drink, or wine mingled with myrrh which is bitterer than gall.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:3
verses.text: Hear what the Prophet has foretold of this: "They gave Me gall to eat, and when I was thirsty they gave Me vinegar to drink".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:4
verses.text: Agreeably with which Moses, even in his day, said to the people, "Their vine is of the vineyards of Sodom, and their branch of Gomorrah; their grape is a grape of gall, and their cluster a cluster of bitterness".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:5
verses.text: And again, the Prophet upbraiding them says, "Oh foolish people and unwise, have ye thus requited the Lord?" Moreover, in the Canticles the same things are foretold, where even the garden in which the Lord was crucified is indicated: "I have come into my garden, my sister, my spouse, and have gathered in my myrrh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 26:6
verses.text: Here the Prophet has plainly set forth the wine mingled with myrrh which the Lord has given Him to drink.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:2
verses.text: Next it is written that "He gave up the ghost".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:3
verses.text: This also had been foretold, by the Prophet, who says, addressing the Father in the Person of the Son, "Into Thy hands I commend My Spirit".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:4
verses.text: He is related also to have been buried, and a great stone laid at the door of the sepulchre.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:5
verses.text: Hear what the word of prophecy foretold by Jeremiah concerning this also, "They have cut off my life in the pit, and have laid a stone upon Me".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:6
verses.text: These words of the Prophet point most plainly to His burial.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:7
verses.text: Here are yet others, "The righteous hath been taken away from beholding iniquity, and his place is in peace".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 27:8
verses.text: And in another place, "I will give the malignant for his burial;" and yet once more, "He hath lain down and slept as a lion, and as a lion's whelp; who shall rouse Him up?".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:2
verses.text: That He descended into hell is also evidently foretold in the Psalms, where it is said, "Thou hast brought Me also into the dust of the death".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:3
verses.text: And again, "What profit is there in my blood, when I shall have descended into corruption?" And again, "I descended into the deep mire, where there is no bottom".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:4
verses.text: Moreover, John says, "Art Thou He that shall come (into hell, without doubt), or do we look for another?" Whence also Peter says that "Christ being put to death in the flesh, but quickened in the Spirit which dwells in Him, descended to the spirits who were shut up in prison, who in the days of Noah believed not, to preach unto them;" where also what He did in hell is declared.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:5
verses.text: Moreover, the Lord says by the Prophet, as though speaking of the future, "Thou wilt not leave my soul in hell, neither wilt Thou suffer Thy Holy One to see corruption".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:6
verses.text: Which again, in prophetic language he speaks of as actually fulfilled, "O Lord, Thou hast brought my soul out of hell: Thou hast saved me from them that go down into the pit".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 28:7
verses.text: There follows next,—.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:2
verses.text: The Third Day He Rose Again from the Dead.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:3
verses.text: The glory of Christ's resurrection threw a lustre upon everything which before had the appearance of weakness and frailty.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:4
verses.text: If a while since it seemed to you impossible that an immortal Being could die, you see now that He who has overcome death and is risen again cannot be mortal.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:5
verses.text: But understand herein the goodness of the Creator, that so far as you by sinning have cast yourself down, so far has He descended in following you.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:6
verses.text: And do not impute lack of power to God, the Creator of all things, by imagining his work to have ended in the fall into an abyss which He in His redemptive purpose was unable to reach.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:7
verses.text: We speak of infernal and supernal, because we are bounded by the definite circumference of the body, and are confined within the limits of the region prescribed to us.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:8
verses.text: But to God, Who is present everywhere and absent nowhere, what is infernal and what supernal? Notwithstanding, through the assumption of a body there is room for these also.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:9
verses.text: The flesh which had been deposited in the sepulchre, is raised, that that might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Prophet, "Thou wilt not suffer Thy Holy One to see corruption".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:10
verses.text: He returned, therefore, a victor from the dead, leading with Him the spoils of hell.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:11
verses.text: For He led forth those who were held in captivity by death, as He Himself had foretold, when He said, "When I shall be lifted up from the earth I shall draw all unto Me".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:12
verses.text: To this the Gospel bears witness, when it says, "The graves were opened, and many bodies of saints which slept arose, and appeared unto many, and entered into the holy City," that city, doubtless, of which the Apostle says, "Jerusalem which is above is free, which is the Mother of us all".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:13
verses.text: As also he says again to the Hebrews, "It became Him, for Whom are all things, and by Whom are all things, Who had brought many sons into glory, to make the Author of their salvation perfect through suffering".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:14
verses.text: Sitting, therefore, on the right hand of God in the highest heavens, He placed there that human flesh, made perfect through sufferings, which had fallen to death by the lapse of the first man, but was now restored by the virtue of the resurrection.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:15
verses.text: Whence also the Apostle says, "Who hath raised us up together and made us sit together in the heavenly places".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:16
verses.text: For He was the potter, Who, as the Prophet Jeremiah teaches, "took up again with His hands, and formed anew, as it seemed good to Him, the vessel which had fallen from His hands and was broken in pieces".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:17
verses.text: And it seemed good to Him that the mortal and corruptible body which He had assumed, this body raised from the rocky sepulchre and rendered immortal and incorruptible, He should now place not on the earth but in heaven, and at His Father's right hand.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:18
verses.text: The Scriptures of the Old Testament are full of these mysteries.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:19
verses.text: No Prophet, no Lawgiver, no Psalmist is silent, but almost every one of the sacred pages speaks of them.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 29:20
verses.text: It seems superfluous, therefore, to linger in collecting testimonies; yet we will cite some few, remitting those who desire to drink more largely to the well-springs of the divine volumes themselves.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:2
verses.text: It is said then in the Psalms, "I laid me down and slept, and rose up again, because the Lord sustained me".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:3
verses.text: Again, in another place, "Because of the wretchedness of the needy and the groaning of the poor, now will I arise, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:4
verses.text: And elsewhere, as we have said above, "O Lord, thou hast brought my soul out of hell; Thou hast saved me from them that go down into the pit".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:5
verses.text: And in another place, "Because Thou hast turned and quickened me, and brought me out of the deep of the earth again".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:6
verses.text: In the 87th Psalm He is most evidently spoken of: "He became as a man without help, free among the dead".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:7
verses.text: It is not said "a man," but "as a man".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:8
verses.text: For in that He descended into hell, He was "as a man:" but He was "free among the dead," because He could not be detained by death.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:9
verses.text: And therefore in the one nature the power of human weakness, in the other the power of divine majesty is exhibited.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:10
verses.text: The Prophet Hosea also speaks most manifestly of the third day in this wise, "After two days He will heal us; but on the third day we shall rise and shall live in His presence".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:11
verses.text: This he says in the person of those who, rising with Him on the third day, are recalled from death to life.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:12
verses.text: And they are the same persons who say, "On the third day we shall rise again, and shall live in His presence".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:13
verses.text: But Isaiah says plainly, "Who brought forth from the earth the great Shepherd of the sheep".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:14
verses.text: Then, that the women were to see His resurrection, while the Scribes and Pharisees and the people disbelieved, this also Isaiah foretold in these words, "Ye women, who come from beholding, come: for it is a people that hath no understanding".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:15
verses.text: But as to the women who are related to have gone to the sepulchre after the resurrection, and to have sought Him without finding, as Mary Magdalene, who is related to have come to the sepulchre before it was light, and not finding Him, to have said, weeping, to the angels who were there, "They have taken away the Lord, and I know not where they have laid Him"—even this is foretold in the Canticles: "On my bed I sought Him Whom my soul loveth; I sought Him in the night, and found Him not".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:16
verses.text: Of those also who found Him, and held Him by the feet, it is foretold, in the same book, "I will hold Him Whom my soul loveth, and will not let Him go".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 30:17
verses.text: Take these passages, a few of many; for being intent on brevity we cannot heap together more.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:2
verses.text: He Ascended into Heaven, and Sitteth on the Right Hand of the Father: from Thence He Shall Come to Judge the Quick and the Dead.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:3
verses.text: These clauses follow with suitable brevity at the end of this part of the Creed which treats of the Son.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:4
verses.text: What is said is plain, but the question is how and in what sense it is to be understood.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:5
verses.text: For to "ascend," and to "sit," and to "come," unless you understand the words in accordance with the dignity of the divine nature, appear to point to something of human weakness.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:6
verses.text: For having consummated what was to be done on earth, and having recalled souls from the captivity of hell, He is spoken of as ascending up to heaven, as the Prophet had foretold, "Ascending up on high He led captivity captive, and gave gifts unto men," those gifts, namely, which Peter, in the Acts of the Apostles, spoke of concerning the Holy Ghost, "Being therefore by the right hand of God exalted, He hath shed forth this gift which ye do see and hear".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:7
verses.text: He gave the gift of the Holy Ghost to men, because the captives, whom the devil had before carried into hell through sin, Christ by His resurrection from death recalled to heaven.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:8
verses.text: He ascended therefore into heaven, not where God the Word had not been before, for He was always in heaven, and abode in the Father, but where the Word made flesh had not been seated before.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:9
verses.text: Lastly, since this entrance within the gates of heaven seemed new to its ministers and princes, they say to one another, on seeing the nature of flesh penetrating into the secret recesses of heaven, as David full of the Holy Ghost, declares, "Lift up your gates, ye princes, and be ye lift up ye everlasting gates, and the King of glory shall enter in.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:10
verses.text: Who is the King of glory? The Lord strong and mighty, the Lord mighty in battle".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:11
verses.text: Which words are spoken not with reference to the power of the divine nature, but with reference to the novelty of flesh ascending to the right hand of God.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:12
verses.text: The same David says elsewhere, "God hath ascended jubilantly, and the Lord with the sound of the trumpet".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:13
verses.text: For conquerors are wont to return from battle with the sound of the trumpet.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:14
verses.text: Of Him also it is said, "Who buildeth up His ascent in heaven".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 31:15
verses.text: And again, "Who hath ascended above the cherubims, flying upon the wings of the winds".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:2
verses.text: To sit at the right hand of the Father is a mystery belonging to the Incarnation.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:3
verses.text: For it does not befit that incorporeal nature without the assumption of flesh; neither is the excellency of a heavenly seat sought for the divine nature, but for the human.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:4
verses.text: Whence it is said of Him, "Thy seat, O God, is prepared from thence forward; Thou art from everlasting".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:5
verses.text: The seat, then, whereon the Lord Jesus was to sit, was prepared from everlasting, "in whose name every knee should bow, of things in heaven and things on earth, and things under the earth; and every tongue shall confess to Him that Jesus is Lord in the glory of God the Father;" of Whom also David thus speaks, "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou on my right hand until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:6
verses.text: Referring to which words the Lord in the Gospel said to the Pharisees, "If therefore David in spirit calleth Him Lord, how is He his Son?" By which He shewed that according to the Spirit He was the Lord, according to the flesh He was the Son, of David.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:7
verses.text: Whence also the Lord Himself says in another place, "Verily I say unto you, henceforth ye shall see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the power of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:8
verses.text: And the Apostle Peter says of Christ, "Who is on the right hand of God, seated in the heavens".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 32:9
verses.text: And Paul also, writing to the Ephesians, "According to the working of the might of His power, which He wrought in Christ, when He raised Him from the dead, and seated Him on His right hand".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33:2
verses.text: That He shall come to judge the quick and the dead we are taught by many testimonies of the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33:3
verses.text: But before we cite what the Prophets say on this point, we think it necessary to remind you that this doctrine of the faith would have us daily solicitous concerning the coming of the Judge, that we may so frame our conduct as having to give account to the Judge who is at hand.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33:4
verses.text: For this is what the Prophet said of the man who is blessed, that, "He ordereth his words in judgment".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 33:5
verses.text: When, however, He is said to judge the quick and the dead, this does not mean that some will come to judgment who are still living, others who are already dead; but that He will judge both souls and bodies, where, by souls are meant "the quick," and the bodies "the dead;" as also the Lord Himself saith in the Gospel, "Fear not them who are able to kill the body, but are not able to hurt the soul; but rather fear Him who is able to destroy both soul and body in Gehenna".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:2
verses.text: Now let us shew briefly, if you will, that these things were foretold by the Prophets.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:3
verses.text: You will yourself, since you are so minded, gather together more from the ample range of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:4
verses.text: The Prophet Malachi says, "Behold the Lord Almighty shall come, and who shall abide the day of His coming, or who shall abide the sight of Him? For He doth come as the fire of a furnace and as fuller's soap: and He shall sit, refining and purifying as it were gold and silver".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:5
verses.text: But that thou mayest know more certainly Who this Lord is of Whom these things are said, hear what the Prophet Daniel also foretells: "I saw," saith he, "in the vision of the night, and, behold, One like the Son of Man coming with the clouds of heaven, and He came nigh to the Ancient of days, and was brought near before Him; and there was given to Him dominion, and honour, and a kingdom.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:6
verses.text: And all peoples, tribes, and languages shall serve Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:7
verses.text: And His dominion is an eternal dominion which shall not pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:8
verses.text: By these words we are taught not only of His coming and judgment, but of His dominion and kingdom, that His dominion is eternal, and His kingdom indestructible, without end; as it is said in the Creed, "and of His kingdom there shall be no end".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:9
verses.text: So that one who says that Christ's kingdom shall one day have an end is very far from the faith.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:10
verses.text: Yet it behoves us to know that the enemy is wont to counterfeit this salutary advent of Christ with cunning fraud in order to deceive the faithful, and in the place of the Son of Man, Who is looked for as coming in the majesty of His Father, to prepare the Son of Perdition with prodigies and lying signs, that instead of Christ he may introduce Antichrist into the world; of whom the Lord Himself warned the Jews beforehand in the Gospels, "Because I am come in My Father's Name, and ye received Me not, another will come in his own name, and him ye will receive".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:11
verses.text: And again, "When ye shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the Prophet, standing in the holy place, let him that readeth understand".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:12
verses.text: Daniel, therefore, in his visions speaks very fully and amply of the coming of that delusion: but it is not worth while to cite instances, for we have enlarged enough already; we therefore refer any one who may wish to know more concerning these matters to the visions themselves.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:13
verses.text: The Apostle also himself says, "Let no than deceive you by any means, for that day shall not come except there come a falling away first, and that man of sin be revealed, the Son of Perdition, who opposeth and exalteth himself above everything that is called God, or that is worshipped, so that he sitteth in the temple of God, shewing himself as though himself were God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:14
verses.text: And soon afterwards, "Then shall that wicked one be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus shall slay with the breath of His mouth, and shall destroy with the brightness of His coming: whose coming is after the working of Satan with all power and signs and lying wonders".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:15
verses.text: And again, shortly afterwards, "And therefore the Lord shall send unto them strong delusion, that they may believe a lie, that all may be judged who have not believed the truth".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:16
verses.text: For this reason, therefore, is this "delusion" foretold unto us by the words of Prophets, Evangelists, and Apostles, lest any one should mistake the coming of Antichrist for the coming of Christ.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:17
verses.text: But as the Lord Himself says, "When they shall say unto you, lo, here is Christ, or lo, He is there, believe it not.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:18
verses.text: For many false Christs and false prophets shall come and shall seduce many".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:19
verses.text: But let us see how He hath pointed out the judgment of the true Christ: "As the lightning shineth from the east unto the west, so shall the coming of the Son of Man be".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:20
verses.text: When, therefore, the true Lord Jesus Christ shall come, He will sit and set up his throne of judgment.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:21
verses.text: As also He says in the Gospel, "He shall separate the sheep from the goats," that is, the righteous from the unrighteous; as the Apostle writes, "We must all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ, that every man may receive the awards due to the body, according as he hath done, whether they be good or evil".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:22
verses.text: Moreover, the judgment will be not only for deeds, but for thoughts also, as the same Apostle saith, "Their thoughts mutually accusing or else excusing one another, in the day when God shall judge the secrets of men".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:23
verses.text: But on these points let this suffice.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 34:24
verses.text: Next follows in the order of the faith,—.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:2
verses.text: And in the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:3
verses.text: What has been delivered above somewhat at large concerning Christ relates to the mystery of His Incarnation and of His Passion, and, by thus intervening, as belonging to His Person, has somewhat delayed the mention of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:4
verses.text: Otherwise, if the divine nature alone be taken into account, as in the beginning of the Creed we say "I believe in God the Father Almighty," and afterwards, "In Jesus Christ His only Son our Lord," so in like manner we add, "And in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:5
verses.text: But all of these particulars which are spoken of above concerning Christ relate, as we have said, to the dispensation of the flesh (to His Incarnation).

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:6
verses.text: By the mention of the Holy Spirit, the mystery of the Trinity is completed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:7
verses.text: For as one Father is mentioned, and there is no other Father, and one only-begotten Son is mentioned, and there is no other only-begotten Son, so also there is one Holy Ghost, and there cannot be another Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:8
verses.text: In order, therefore, that the Persons may be distinguished, the terms expressing relationship (the properties) are varied, whereby the first is understood to be the Father, of Whom are all things, Who Himself also hath no Father, the second the Son, as born of the Father, and the third the Holy Ghost, as proceeding from both, and sanctifying all things.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:9
verses.text: But that in the Trinity one and the same Godhead may be set forth, since, prefixing the preposition "in" we say that we believe "in God the Father," so also we say, "in Christ His Son," so also "in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:10
verses.text: But our meaning will be made more plain in what follows.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 35:11
verses.text: For the Creed proceeds,—.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:2
verses.text: "The Holy Church; The Forgiveness of Sin, the Resurrection of This Flesh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:3
verses.text: It is not said, "In the holy Church," nor "In the forgiveness of sins," nor "In the resurrection of the flesh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:4
verses.text: For if the preposition "in" had been added, it would have had the same force as in the preceding articles.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:5
verses.text: But now in those clauses in which the faith concerning the Godhead is declared, we say "In God the Father," and "In Jesus Christ His Son," and "In the Holy Ghost," but in the rest, where we speak not of the Godhead but of creatures and mysteries, the preposition "in " is not added.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:6
verses.text: We do not say "We believe in the holy Church," but "We believe the holy Church," not as God, but as the Church gathered together to God: and we believe that there is "forgiveness of sins;" we do not say "We believe in the forgiveness of sins;" and we believe that there will be a "Resurrection of the flesh;" we do not say "We believe in the resurrection of the flesh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:7
verses.text: By this monosyllabic preposition, therefore, the Creator is distinguished from the creatures, and things divine are separated from things human.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:8
verses.text: This then is the Holy Ghost, who in the Old Testament inspired the Law and the Prophets, in the New the Gospels and the Epistles.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:9
verses.text: Whence also the Apostle says, "All Scripture given by inspiration of God is profitable for instruction".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 36:10
verses.text: And therefore it seems proper in this place to enumerate, as we have learnt from the tradition of the Fathers, the books of the New and of the Old Testament, which, according to the tradition of our forefathers, are believed to have been inspired by the Holy Ghost, and have been handed down to the Churches of Christ.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:2
verses.text: Of the Old Testament, therefore, first of all there have been handed down five books of Moses, Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy; Then Jesus Nave, (Joshua the son of Nun), The Book of Judges together with Ruth; then four books of Kings (Reigns), which the Hebrews reckon two; the Book of Omissions, which is entitled the Book of Days (Chronicles), and two books of Ezra (Ezra and Nehemiah), which the Hebrews reckon one, and Esther; of the Prophets, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and Daniel; moreover of the twelve (minor) Prophets, one book; Job also and the Psalms of David, each one book.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:3
verses.text: Solomon gave three books to the Churches, Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Canticles.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:4
verses.text: These comprise the books of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:5
verses.text: Of the New there are four Gospels, Matthew, Mark, Luke, John; the Acts of the Apostles, written by Luke; fourteen Epistles of the Apostle Paul, two of the Apostle Peter, one of James, brother of the Lord and Apostle, one of Jude, three of John, the Revelation of John.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 37:6
verses.text: These are the books which the Fathers have comprised within the Canon, and from which they would have us deduce the proofs of our faith.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:2
verses.text: But it should be known that there are also other books which our fathers call not "Canonical" but "Ecclesiastical:" that is to say, Wisdom, called the Wisdom of Solomon, and another Wisdom, called the Wisdom of the Son of Syrach, which last-mentioned the Latins called by the general title Ecclesiasticus, designating not the author of the book, but the character of the writing.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:3
verses.text: To the same class belong the Book of Tobit, and the Book of Judith, and the Books of the Maccabees.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:4
verses.text: In the New Testament the little book which is called the Book of the Pastor of Hermas, [and that] which is called The Two Ways, or the Judgment of Peter; all of which they would have read in the Churches, but not appealed to for the confirmation of doctrine.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:5
verses.text: The other writings they have named "Apocrypha".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:6
verses.text: These they would not have read in the Churches.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 38:7
verses.text: These are the traditions which the Fathers have handed down to us, which, as I said, I have thought it opportune to set forth in this place, for the instruction of those who are being taught the first elements of the Church and of the Faith, that they may know from what fountains of the Word of God their draughts must be taken.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:2
verses.text: We come next in the order of belief to the Holy Church.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:3
verses.text: We have mentioned above why the Creed does not say here, as in the preceding article, "In the Holy Church".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:4
verses.text: They, therefore, who were taught above to believe in one God, under the mystery of the Trinity, must believe this also, that there is one holy Church in which there is one faith and one baptism, in which is believed one God the Father, and one Lord Jesus Christ, His Son, and one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:5
verses.text: This is that holy Church which is without spot or wrinkle.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:6
verses.text: For many others have gathered together Churches, as Marcion, and Valentinus, and Ebion, and Manichaeus, and Arius, and all the other heretics.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:7
verses.text: But those Churches are not without spot or wrinkle of unfaithfulness.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:8
verses.text: And therefore the Prophet said of them, "I hate the Church of the malignants, and I will not sit with the ungodly".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:9
verses.text: But of this Church which keeps the faith of Christ entire, hear what the Holy Spirit says in the Canticles, "My dove is one; the perfect one of her mother is one".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:10
verses.text: He then who receives this faith in the Church let him not turn aside in the Council of vanity, and let him not enter in with those who practise iniquity.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:11
verses.text: For Marcion's assembly is a Council of vanity in that he denies that the Father of Christ is God, the Creator, who by His Son made the world.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:12
verses.text: Ebion's is a Council of vanity since he teaches that, while we believe in Christ, we are withal to observe the circumcision of the flesh, the keeping of the Sabbath, the accustomed sacrifices, and all the other ordinances according to the letter of the Law.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:13
verses.text: Manichaeus' is a Council of vanity in regard of his teaching; first in that he calls himself the Paraclete, then that he says that the world was made by an evil God, denies God the Creator, rejects the Old Testament, asserts two natures, one good the other evil, mutually opposing one another, affirms that men's souls are co-eternal with God, that, according to the Pythagoreans, they return through divers circles of nativity into cattle and animals and beasts, denies the resurrection of our flesh, maintains that the passion and nativity of the Lord were not in the verity of flesh, but only in appearance.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:14
verses.text: It was the Council of vanity when Paul of Samosata and his successor Photinus afterwards taught, that Christ was not born of the Father before the world, but had His beginning from Mary, and believed not that being God He was born man, but that of man He was made God.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:15
verses.text: It was the Council of vanity when Arius and Eunomius taught as their determinate opinion that the Son of God was not born of the very substance of the Father, but was created out of nothing, and that the Son of God had a beginning, and is inferior to the Father: moreover they affirm that the Holy Ghost is not only inferior to the Son, but is also a ministering Spirit.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:16
verses.text: Theirs also is a Council of vanity who confess indeed that the Son is of the substance of the Father, but distinguish and separate the Holy Spirit, while yet the Saviour shews in the Gospel that the power and Godhead of the Trinity are one and the same, saying, "Baptize all nations in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost," and it is plainly impious for man to put asunder what God hath joined together.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:17
verses.text: That also is the Council of vanity which a pertinacious and wicked contention formerly gathered together, affirming that Christ assumed human flesh indeed, but not a rational soul withal, since Christ conferred one and the same salvation on the flesh, and the animal soul, and the reason and mind of man.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:18
verses.text: That also is the Council of vanity which Donatus drew together throughout Africa, by charging the Church with traditorship (delivering up the sacred books), and with which Novatus disturbed men's minds by denying the grant of repentance to the lapsed, and condemning second marriages, though contracted possibly of necessity.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:19
verses.text: All of these then avoid as congregations of malignants.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:20
verses.text: Those also, if such there be, who are said to assert that the Son of God does not see or know the Father, as Himself is known and seen by the Father; or that the kingdom of Christ will have an end; or that the flesh will not be raised in the complete restoration of its substance; these also who deny that there will be a just judgment of God in respect of all, and affirm that the devil will be absolved from the punishment of damnation due to him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:21
verses.text: To all these, I say, let the believer turn a deaf ear.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 39:22
verses.text: But hold fast by the holy Church, which confesses God the Father Almighty, and His only Son, Jesus Christ our Lord, and the Holy Ghost, of one concordant and harmonious substance, believes that the Son of God was born of the Virgin, suffered for man's salvation, rose again from the dead in the same flesh in which he was born; and, lastly, hopes that He will come the Judge of all, through Whom also both the Forgiveness of Sins and the Resurrection of the Flesh are preached.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:2
verses.text: As to the Forgiveness of Sins, it ought to be enough simple to believe.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:3
verses.text: For who would ask the cause or the reason when a Prince grants indulgence? When the liberality of an earthly sovereign is no fit subject for discussion, shall man's temerity discuss God's largess? For the Pagans are wont to ridicule us, saying that we deceive ourselves, fancying that crimes committed in deed can be purged by words.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:4
verses.text: And they say, "Can he who has committed murder be no murderer, and he who has committed adultery be accounted no adulterer? How then shall one guilty of crimes of this sort all of a sudden be made holy?" But to this, as I said, we answer better by faith than by reason.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:5
verses.text: For he is King of all who hath promised it: He is Lord of heaven and earth who assures us of it.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:6
verses.text: Would you have me refuse to believe that He who made me a man of the dust of the earth can of a guilty person make me innocent? And that He who when I was blind made me see, or when I was deaf made me hear, or lame walk, can recover for me my lost innocence? And to come to the witness of Nature—to kill a man is not always criminal, but to kill of malice, not by law, is criminal.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:7
verses.text: It is not the deed then, in such matters, that condemns me, because sometimes it is rightly done, but the evil intention of the mind.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:8
verses.text: If then my mind which had been rendered criminal, and in which the sin originated, is corrected, why should I seem to you incapable of being made innocent, who before was criminal? For if it is plain, as I have shewn, that crime consists not in the deed but in the will, as an evil will, prompted by an evil demon, has made me obnoxious to sin and death, so the will prompted by the good God, being changed to good, hath restored me to innocence and life.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:9
verses.text: It is the same also in all other crimes.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 40:10
verses.text: In this way there is found to be no opposition between our faith and natural reason, while forgiveness of sins is imputed not to deeds, which when once done cannot be changed, but to the mind, which it is certain can be converted from bad to good.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:2
verses.text: This last article, which affirms the Resurrection of the Flesh, concludes the sum of all perfection with succinct brevity.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:3
verses.text: Although on this point also the faith of the Church is impugned, not only by Gentiles, but by heretics likewise.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:4
verses.text: For Valentinus altogether denies the resurrection of the flesh, so do the Manicheans, as we shewed above.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:5
verses.text: But they refuse to listen to the Prophet Isaiah when he says, "The dead shall rise, and they who are in the graves shall be raised," or to most wise Daniel, when he declares, "Then they who are in the dust of the earth shall arise, these to eternal life, but those to shame and confusion".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:6
verses.text: Yet even in the Gospels, which they appear to receive, they ought to learn from our Lord and Saviour, Who says, when instructing the Sadducees, "As touching the resurrection of the dead: have ye not read how He saith to Moses in the Bush, I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, the God of Jacob? Now God is not the God of the dead but of the living".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:7
verses.text: Where in what goes before He declares what and how great is the glory of the resurrection, saying, "But in the resurrection of the dead they will neither marry or be given in marriage, but will be as the angels of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 41:8
verses.text: But the virtue of the resurrection confers on men an angelical state, so that they who have risen from the earth shall not live again on the earth with the brute animals but with angels in heaven—yet those only whose purer life has fitted them for this—those, namely, who even now preserving the flesh of their soul in chastity, have brought it into subjection to the Holy Spirit, and thus with every stain of sins done away and changed into spiritual glory by the virtue of sanctification, have been counted worthy to have it admitted into the society of angels.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 42

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 42:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 42:2
verses.text: But unbelievers cry, "How can the flesh, which has been putrified and dissolved, or changed into dust, sometimes also swallowed up by the sea, and dispersed by the waves, be gathered up again, and again made one, and a man's body formed anew out of it?" To whom our first answer is in Paul's words: "Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened, except it die.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 42:3
verses.text: And that which thou sowest, thou sowest not the body, which shall be, but bare grain of wheat or of some other seed: but God giveth it a body as seemeth good to Him".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 42:4
verses.text: Did you not believe that that which you see taking place every year in the seeds which you cast into the ground will come to pass in your flesh which by the law of God is sown in the earth? Why, pray, have you so mean an opinion of God's power that you do not believe it possible for the scattered dust of which each man's flesh was composed to be re-collected and restored to its own original fabric? Do you refuse to admit the fact when you see mortal ingenuity search for veins of metal deeply buried in the ground, and the experienced eye discover gold where the inexperienced thinks there is nothing but earth? Why should we refuse to grant these things to Him who made man, when he whom He made can do so much? And when mortal ingenuity discovers that gold has its own proper vein, and silver another, and that a far different vein of copper, and diverse and distinct veins of iron and lead lie concealed beneath what has the appearance of earth, shall divine power be thought unable to discover and distinguish the component particles belonging to each man's flesh, even though they seem to be dispersed?.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:2
verses.text: But let us endeavour to assist those souls which fail in their faith through reasons drawn from nature.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:3
verses.text: If one should mix different sorts of seeds together and sow them indiscriminately in the earth, will not the grain of each several kind, wherever it may have been thrown, shoot forth at the proper time in accordance with its own specific nature so as to reproduce the condition of its own form and its own body.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:4
verses.text: Thus then the substance of each individual flesh, though its particles have been variously and diversely scattered, has within it an immortal principle, since it is the flesh of an immortal soul, and at the time which God in His good pleasure shall appoint, there will be collected from the earth and drawn to it, its own component particles, which will be restored to that form which death had formerly dissolved.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:5
verses.text: And thus it will come to pass that to each soul will be restored, not a confused or foreign body but its own which it had when alive, in order that the flesh together with its own soul may for the conflicts of the present life either be crowned if undefiled, or punished if defiled.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:6
verses.text: And accordingly our Church, in teaching the faith instead of "the Resurrection of the flesh," as the Creed is delivered in other Churches, guardedly adds the pronoun "this"—"the resurrection of this flesh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:7
verses.text: "Of this," that is, no doubt, of the person who rehearses the Creed, making the sign of the cross upon his forehead, while he says the word, that each believer may know that his flesh, if he have kept it clean from sin, will be a vessel of honour, useful to the Lord, prepared for every good work; but, if defiled by sins, that it will be a vessel of wrath destined to destruction.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:8
verses.text: But now, concerning the glory of the resurrection and the greatness of the promise by which God has bound Himself, if any one desires to be more fully informed, he will find notices in almost all the divine volumes, out of which, simply by way of bringing them to remembrance, we will mention a few passages in the present place, and then make an end of the work which you have enjoined.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:9
verses.text: The Apostle Paul makes use of such arguments as the following in asserting that mortal flesh will rise again.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:10
verses.text: "But if there be no resurrection of the dead, then is not Christ risen.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:11
verses.text: And if Christ be not risen, our preaching is vain and your faith is vain".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:12
verses.text: And presently afterwards, "But now is Christ risen from the dead, the first-fruits of them that sleep.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:13
verses.text: For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:14
verses.text: For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:15
verses.text: But every man in his own order.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:16
verses.text: Christ the first-fruits, afterwards they that are Christ's at His coming, then cometh the end".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:17
verses.text: And afterways he adds, "Behold I shew you a mystery: We shall all rise indeed, but we shall not all be changed;" or as other copies read, "We shall all sleep, indeed but we shall not all be changed; in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump; for the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall rise incorruptible, and we shall be changed".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:18
verses.text: However, whichever be the true text, writing to the Thessalonians, he says, "I would not have you ignorant, brethren, concerning those who are asleep, that ye sorrow not, as the others who have no hope.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:19
verses.text: For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, so those also who sleep through Jesus shall God bring with Him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:20
verses.text: For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain at the coming of the Lord shall not prevent them that sleep.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 43:21
verses.text: For the Lord Himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, with the trump of God, and the dead who are in Christ shall rise first: then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet Christ in the air, and so shall we ever be with the Lord".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:2
verses.text: But that you may not suppose this to be a novel doctrine peculiar to Paul, I will adduce also what the Prophet Ezekiel foretold by the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:3
verses.text: "Behold," saith he, "I will open your graves and bring you forth out of your graves".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:4
verses.text: Let me recall, further, how Job, who abounds in mystical language, plainly predicts the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:5
verses.text: "There is hope for a tree; for if it be cut down it will sprout again, and its shoot shall never fail.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:6
verses.text: But if its root have waxed old in the earth, and the stock thereof be dead in the dust, yet through the scent of water it will flourish again, and put forth shoots as a young plant.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 44:7
verses.text: But man, if he be dead, is he departed and gone? And mortal man, if he have fallen, shall he be no more?" Dost thou not see, that in these words he is appealing to men's sense of shame, as it were, and saying, "Is mankind so foolish, that when they see the stock of a tree which has been cut down shooting forth again from the ground, and dead wood again restored to life, they imagine their own case to have no likeness to that of wood or trees?" But to convince you that Job's words are to be read as a question, when he says, "But mortal man when he hath fallen shall he not rise again?" take this proof from what follows; for he adds immediately, "But if a man be dead, shall he live?" And presently afterwards he says, "I will wait till I be made again;" and afterwards he repeats the same: "Who shall raise again upon the earth my skin, which is now draining this cup of suffering?".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45:2
verses.text: Thus much in proof of the profession which we make in the Creed when we say "The resurrection of this flesh".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45:3
verses.text: As to the addition "this" see how consonant it is with all that we have cited from the divine books.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45:4
verses.text: What else does Job signify in the place which we explained above, "He will raise again my skin, which is now draining this cup of suffering," that is, which is undergoing these torments? Does he not plainly say that there will be a resurrection of this flesh, this, I mean, which is now undergoing the extremity of trials and tribulations? Moreover, when the Apostle says, "This corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality," are not his words those of one who in a manner touches his body and places his finger upon it? This body then, which is now corruptible, will by the grace of the resurrection be incorruptible, and this which is now mortal will be clothed with virtues of immortality, that, as "Christ rising from the dead dieth no more, death hath no more dominion over Him," so those who shall rise in Christ shall never again feel corruption or death, not because the nature of flesh will have been cast off, but because its condition and quality will have been changed.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 45:5
verses.text: There will be a body, therefore, which will rise from the dead incorruptible and immortal, not only of the righteous, but also of sinners; of the righteous that they may be able ever to abide with Christ, of sinners that they may undergo without end the punishment due to them.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:2
verses.text: That the righteous shall ever abide with Christ our Lord we have proved above, where we have shewn that the Apostle says, "Then we which are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet Christ in the air, and so shall we ever be with the Lord".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:3
verses.text: And do not marvel that the flesh of the saints is to be changed into such a glorious condition at the resurrection as to be caught up to meet God, suspended in the clouds and borne in the air, since the same Apostle, setting forth the great things which God bestows on them that love Him, says, "Who shall change our vile body that it may be made like unto His glorious body".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:4
verses.text: It is nowise absurd then, if the bodies of the saints are said to be raised up into the air, seeing that they are said to be renewed after the image of Christ's body, which is seated at God's right hand.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:5
verses.text: But this also the holy Apostle adds, speaking either of himself or of others of his own place or merit, "He will raise us up together with Christ and make us sit together in the heavenly places".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:6
verses.text: Whence, since God's saints have these promises and an infinite number like them respecting the resurrection of the righteous, it will now not be difficult to believe those also which the Prophets have foretold, namely, that "the righteous shall shine as the sun and as the brightness of the firmament in the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:7
verses.text: For who will think it difficult that they should have the brightness of the sun, and be adorned with the splendour of the stars and of this firmament, for whom the life and conversation of God's angels are being prepared in heaven, or who are represented as being hereafter to be conformed to the glory of Christ's body? In reference to which glory, promised by the Saviour's mouth, the holy Apostle says, "It is sown as an animal body; it will rise a spiritual body".

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 46:8
verses.text: For if it is true, as it certainly is true, that God will vouchsafe to associate every one of the righteous and of the saints in companionship with the angels, it is certain that He will change their bodies also into the glory of a spiritual body.

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47:2
verses.text: Nor let this promise seem to you contrary to the natural structure of the body.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47:3
verses.text: For if we believe, according to what is written, that God took clay of the earth and made man, and that the origin of our body was this, that, by the will of God, earth was changed into flesh, why does it seem absurd to you or contrary to reason if, on the same principles on which earth is said to be advanced to all animal body, an animal body in turn should be believed to be advanced to a spiritual body? These things and many like these you will find in the divine Scriptures concerning the resurrection of the righteous.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47:4
verses.text: There will be given to sinners also, as we said above, a condition of incorruption and immortality at the resurrection, that, as God assigns this state to the righteous for perpetuity of glory, so He may assign the same to sinners for prolongation of confusion and punishment.

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 47:5
verses.text: For this also the Prophet's words, which we referred to above, state clearly: "Many shall rise from the dust of the earth, some to life eternal, and others to confusion and eternal shame".

chapters.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 48

verses.name: Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 48:1
Rufinus: Commentary on the Apostles' Creed 48:2
verses.text: If then we have understood in what august significance God Almighty is called Father, and in what mysterious sense our Lord Jesus Christ is held to be His only Son, and with what entire perfection of meaning His Spirit is called the Holy Spirit, and how the Holy Trinity is one in substance but has distinctions of relation and of Persons, what also is the birth from a Virgin, what the nativity of the Word in the flesh, what the mystery of the Cross, what the purpose of our Lord's descent into hell, what the glory of the Resurrection, and the delivery of souls from their captivity in the infernal regions, what also His ascension into heaven, and the expected advent of the Judge; moreover how the holy Church ought to be acknowledged as opposed to the congregations of vanity, what is the number of the sacred Volume, what conventicles of heretics ought to be avoided, and how in the forgiveness of sins there is no opposition whatever between the divine freedom and natural reason, and how not only the sacred oracles but also the example of Lord and Saviour Himself, and the conclusions of natural reason, confirm the truth of the resurrection of our flesh;—if, I say, we have intelligently followed these in succession in accordance with the rule of the tradition hereinbefore expounded, we pray that the Lord will grant to us, and to all who hear these words, that having kept the faith which we have received, having finished our course, we may await the crown of righteousness laid up for us, and be found among those who shall rise again to eternal life, and be delivered from confusion and eternal shame, through Christ our Lord, through Whom to God the Father Almighty with the Holy Ghost is glory and dominion for ever and ever, Amen.
